title: Problem Overview
content: **Erdős Problem #266** presents Stolarsky's conjecture: for any convergent ∑1/aₙ, some integer shift t should make ∑1/(aₙ+t) irrational. Kovač-Tao (2024) disproved this with a remarkable counterexample.
mathContext: The conjecture seemed natural: with infinitely many shift choices, surely one should 'break' any rationality pattern. But the counterexample shows sequences can be constructed to maintain rationality under ALL shifts.

title: Mathlib Imports
content: We import **Data.Real.Irrational** for irrationality, **InfiniteSum.Real** for summability and tsum, and **Rat.Cast.Lemmas** for rational number coercions.

title: Stolarsky's Conjecture
content: **Stolarsky's Conjecture**: For any sequence aₙ of positive integers with convergent ∑1/aₙ, there exists some t ≥ 1 such that ∑1/(aₙ + t) is irrational.
mathContext: Formally: `∀ a, (∀ n, 1 ≤ a n) → Summable (1/a) → ∃ t ≥ 1, Irrational (∑' 1/(a + t))`. The conjecture asks for existence of at least one 'irrationality-producing' shift.

title: Kovač-Tao Disproof
content: **Kovač-Tao (2024)**: Stolarsky's conjecture is FALSE. There exist sequences where NO integer shift produces irrationality — all shifts give rational sums.
mathContext: Stated as `¬StolarskyConjecture`. The proof constructs an explicit counterexample sequence using techniques from Ahmes series theory.

title: All-Rationals Result
content: **Stronger Result**: There exists a strictly increasing sequence aₙ where ∑1/(aₙ + t) is RATIONAL for ALL t ∈ ℚ (avoiding poles). Not just integers — ALL rational shifts!
mathContext: This extraordinary rigidity: `∃ a, StrictMono a ∧ ∀ t : ℚ, (valid) → ∃ q : ℚ, ∑' 1/(a + t) = q`. The sequence simultaneously avoids irrationality for uncountably many shifts.

title: Counterexample Construction
content: The counterexample sequence is carefully constructed so that: (1) ∑1/aₙ converges, and (2) for any shift t, the sum telescopes or simplifies to a rational value.
mathContext: The construction uses deep techniques from Ahmes series (Egyptian fractions). The sequence must balance convergence requirements with the algebraic structure needed for rational sums under all shifts.

title: Relation to Problem #264
content: This problem is closely related to Erdős #264 (irrationality sequences). Both ask: how robust is irrationality under additive perturbations?
mathContext: #264 asks about variable perturbations bₙ; #266 asks about constant shifts t. Kovač-Tao's unified approach resolved both: perturbations can always be found to maintain rationality.

title: Harmonic Series Diverges
content: The harmonic series ∑1/n diverges, so it doesn't satisfy the convergence hypothesis of Stolarsky's conjecture.
mathContext: This is a prerequisite check: the conjecture only applies to convergent series. Divergent series like the harmonic one are excluded.

title: Sum of Reciprocal Squares
content: The series ∑1/n² converges (to π²/6 by the Basel problem), so sequences like aₙ = n² ARE candidates for Stolarsky's conjecture.
mathContext: This shows non-trivial sequences satisfy the convergence hypothesis. For such 'natural' sequences, it's unknown whether some shift produces irrationality.

title: Geometric Series
content: The geometric series ∑1/2ⁿ converges to 2. This is a basic example of a convergent series satisfying the hypothesis.
mathContext: For geometric sequences, the shifted sum ∑1/(2ⁿ + t) also converges for any t ≥ 0. Whether some shift produces irrationality is related to Erdős #264's question about 2ⁿ.

title: Shifted Geometric Series
content: The shifted geometric ∑1/(2ⁿ + 1) also converges, by comparison with the unshifted geometric series.
mathContext: Since 2ⁿ + 1 > 2ⁿ, we have 1/(2ⁿ + 1) < 1/2ⁿ, so the shifted series is dominated by the convergent geometric series.
